context: The groundwater of the quarternary aquifer in Bitterfeld was pumped through several different remediation reactors located in wells directly above the groundwater table in 23m depth below surface (Weiss et al., 2001). The groundwater was then pumped to the laboratory into a thermostated fridge (15°C) and by the use of different valves treated (from the outflow of several remediation reactors) and untreated groundwater could individually be selected for the analysis through the biomonitor system or for chemical analysis. Fig. 1 depicts a schematic view of the groundwater circuit in the SAFIRA pilotplant with the illustration of the biomonitor system for remediation process control, detoxification efficiency and evaluation.Physico-chemical parameters Before the treated groundwater was tested with the biomonitor system, pH, conductivity, temperature and hydrogensulfide concentrations were continuously measured in a vitreous multisensor measuring chamber.Single dose and mixture toxicity experiments A static luminescent bacteria test (LUMISTOX©) with freshly prepared bacteria (s. above) was used to determine the dose response relationships for the bacteria and synthetic groundwater and the volatile organics (VOCs) benzene, monochlorobenzene, 1,2- and 1,4-dichlorobenzene, 2-chlorotoluene, ethylbenzene and the toxic effects to these bacteria (1ml test volume). Stock solutions of all VOCs were prepared in methanol. Testing solutions were prepared freshly every day via dilution of the stock substances in 2% NaCl solution. Methanol concentration was set to 0.1% in all tests.
